content.description: For which of the following functions is the chain rule an appropriate method to find the derivative with respect to <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> ?
content.question: <math alttext="y equals, the sine of open parenthesis, 3 times x squared, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>sin</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mn>3</mn><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="y equals, e to the x power, times tangent x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mi>e</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></msup><mi>tan</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math><math alttext="y equals, the fraction with numerator 1, and denominator 8 times x to the fourth power, minus 2 x, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>8</mn><msup><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>

unit.text: 3: Differentiation: Composite, Implicit, and Inverse Functions

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the classification of a given expression (e.g., Use the chain rule to find the derivative of a composite function).
